posts.name: Elliot S
posts.cooked: Hi CD, here is my quick rant about product specs from FRC vendors. So, specs mean maximum revolutions per minute, maximum static load, and maximum dynamic load. These are critical factors in determining if a product will perform under expected conditions. Looking through the specs, I noticed that some sites don't provide detailed information, relying instead on user guides or datasheets. For instance, McMaster-Carr offers comprehensive resources for nearly every product, whereas others require digging deeper or consulting manufacturers. In comparison, McMaster, McMaster Carr, Bearings Direct, Online Metals, Molex, and Strapworks provide varying levels of detail. For bearings and bushings, key specs include RPM, static load, and dynamic load capacities. Other considerations like tolerances and bearing numbers can be helpful. Overall, students should learn how to identify reliable sources and utilize them to design more durable and efficient systems. VEX and FIRST Robotics Competition vendors should improve their spec offerings to meet market demands.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
So many times a great opportunity to teach engineering is ruined or at least made much more difficult by this. It is an unfortunate reality of the current state of FIRST Robotics Competition vendors. I would love to be able to ask students why they choose parts and have the answer be “because it is within the specs and therefore is a good option” rather than “other teams have used this part that has no specs with success, so it will probably work for us too.”  

The lack of specs makes even calculating what it would need to be, a great teaching exercise, have little motivation.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked: It’s not clear what you’re asking for here; I think the current approach is acceptable for 95% of cases. The McMaster bearings specifications are crafted to suit non-technical buyers, enabling engineers to pair an item with various compatible parts. The engineering specs must be broad enough to allow any part meeting or surpassing them to be approved for use over several years. However, if a part fails to meet its specs, it will require investigation and remediation at vendors’ costs, which could take years. The FRC vendor standard for mechanical parts states, “we used them and they did fine, here’s CAD to 0.002in,” which works well for our market since we don’t invest in extensive spec validation for vendors. We lack a system to retrofit FRC robots with suitable bearings due to the time needed for load case measurement and validation, which is essential for drafting service agreements and warranties. Additionally, changing this approach would be costly, considering the trust issues inherent in the FRC market—hobbyist in nature—with sloppier fits and guesswork. Such changes might involve fixing issues like non-uniform hexfits, last seen around 2017 and now commonly addressed with rounded hexagons.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: Please ensure we are not asked to request detailed information about the number of strands in the wire or the specifications of the bushings we purchase from them. Additionally, please avoid any in-depth testing or investigation. We only require basic details that provide meaningful educational opportunities, rather than being overwhelmed by dull technical specifications.

posts.name: s-neff
posts.cooked:
Here’s a refined version of your text:

The user shared insights about evaluating specifications when considering parts. One perspective suggests choosing components within known standards for reliability, while another highlights leveraging existing knowledge about specific manufacturers’ products.tribal knowledge could enhance platforms like frcdesign.org but shouldn’t undermine vendor credibility. The user also questioned details like wire strand count and bushing specs, emphasizing the importance of understanding component origins and specifications. Additionally, the user expressed doubts about certain mechanical parts relying on CAD compatibility and discussed the practicality of components based on available information.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
The original manufacturer's specs for bushings sold by the manufacturer should be shared. It is preferable to provide basic information for educational purposes rather than extensive testing or investigation. The focus should be on teaching engineering principles rather than engaging in "bro-science."

Reposting factory specs such as RPMs on bearings or wire strand counts is sensible for resale products. However, for custom FRC (First Robotics Competition) items, providing formal specs or validation is challenging and less justified.

When considering custom bushings designed for a rounded hex shaft, it is important to include margins for potential shaft misalignment. Teams may complain if the bushing binds due to alignment issues, even if it deviates from the original specifications.

Spec sheets often lack specific details needed in professional settings, highlighting the value of "qualified by similarity." Engineering discussions about applicable conditions and differences between uses are crucial and should be encouraged.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: I think you are reading too much into what I said. I agree with you.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked:
The number of times a spec sheet doesn’t include what I need in my day job is significant—what you're referring to as "bro-science" is actually a real aspect of engineering. The term "qualified by similarity" exists and refers to applying conditions from the original use case when adapting it for different applications. Discussing these differences can be beneficial.

An anecdote for those not privy to this context: A few months back, while attempting to specify a sluice gate valve for a client, the vendor only provided an incomplete catalog drawing with schematic illustrations. When asked for additional dimensions, there was silence—a $80k valve compared to the capital environment of FRC.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: I've come to realize that determining accurate load or speed ratings for round corner hex in metal bushings will be quite challenging without actual testing. When dealing with round shafts in round holes, one can obtain some load ratings, and when considering the involvement of oil, calculating where the shaft lifts off and floats within the oil film becomes feasible. This involves utilizing abbreviations like PV (pressure times velocity) along with somewhat vague calculations. Additionally, plastic bearings tend to expand with heat and moisture, complicating matters further. Another important point is that round corner hex does not allow for liftoff; instead, the operational zone remains narrow, and misalignment exacerbates issues.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Yeah, even if there were published specs, actual performance in any given application may not match up. I had consulting project once where an automation company was having bearing failures on one of their products. They had tried a bunch of different suppliers, including all the most expensive name brands, before giving up and spending thousands on outside consultants. All the math we could come up with showed that those bearings should have been fine, but switching them out with slightly larger ones fixed everything. FRC bots see very high vibrations, often very poor build quality and assembly practices and the service life of an FRC bot is extremely short. The specs you find on McMaster or those other websites are based on conditions totally unlike ours and shouldn’t be trusted much anyway.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked: The specs you find on McMaster or those other websites are based on conditions totally unlike ours and shouldn’t be trusted much anyway. Very much this. If you look at Gates’ official load ratings for HTD 5mm belts, for example, you’ll find that we routinely use them out-of-spec (by a factor of two or so!) in the FIRST Robotics Competition.

posts.name: Matt Carroll
posts.cooked: The bearing from McMaster costs $7.50, and the West Coast Products equivalent is $2.00. I plan to offer FIRST Robotics Competition vendors a discount if their product pages lack detailed engineering specifications, similar to what McMaster has provided. If I can acquire a product for significantly less yet maintain comparable quality, I will invest some time to identify something comparable that the product likely handles effectively.
